title: Cloud Computing
tagLine: Master the art of Cloud Computing
description: Enroll in our Cloud Computing program to explore the future of technology and ensure a bright tomorrow!
overView: Cloud computing is a paradigm that delivers computing services, including storage, processing power, and software applications, over the internet.

It offers various service models such as Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS), Platform as a Service (PaaS), and Software as a Service (SaaS), allowing users to access resources on-demand without the need for managing physical hardware.
Deployment models include public, private, and hybrid clouds, each offering different levels of control and customization.
Cloud computing provides benefits such as scalability, cost-efficiency, flexibility, and accessibility, but also presents challenges related to security, reliability, and vendor lock-in.
Overall, it revolutionizes IT infrastructure by enabling organizations to efficiently utilize resources and focus on innovation and business growth.

title: Basics of mechanical engineering, Mechanical design and development
tagLine: Master the art of Mechanical design and development
description: This course introduces the fundamental principles of mechanical engineering, with a centre of attention on mechanical design and development. Students will acquire a comprehensive understanding of the core concepts of mechanical engineering, theories, and methodologies essential for designing and developing mechanical systems and components. Through a combination of theoretical lectures, practical exercises, and hands-on projects, participants will learn how to apply engineering principles to solve real-world problems in the field of mechanical design.
overView: To present students to the foundational concepts and principles of mechanical engineering and design.
To Introduce students with the basics of mechanical design, including design processes, methodologies, and standards.
To Develop problem-solving skills and critical thinking abilities in the context of mechanical design and development.
To explore advanced topics in mechanical engineering, such as finite element analysis (FEA), computer-aided design (CAD), and simulation techniques.
To encourage the students by teamwork, collaboration, and effective communication skills through group projects and presentations.
To prepare students for further studies or careers in mechanical engineering and related fields.

faq.question: Finite Element Analysis (FEA) and Computational Fluid Dynamics (CFD)

title: Basic CAD modeling using CATIA, SOLIDWORKS
description: This course provides an introduction to Computer-Aided Design (CAD) using CATIA and SOLIDWORKS software. Participants will learn fundamental principles and techniques for creating 3D models, assemblies, and drawings using these industry-standard CAD tools. Through hands-on exercises and practical examples, students will gain proficiency in creating geometric shapes, applying constraints, and generating engineering drawings. This two CAD software’s are widely used in industries. No prior experience in CAD is required, although familiarity with basic engineering concepts and computer usage is beneficial.
overView: Understand the basics of CAD software interface and functionality.
Learn how to create and modify 3D models using CATIA and SOLIDWORKS.
Explore various sketching techniques for creating 2D profiles.
Master the use of features such as extrusions, revolve, sweeps, and lofts.
Practice assembling components and creating assembly constraints.
Generate detailed engineering drawings with annotations and dimensions.
Develop proficiency in navigating the software environment and customizing settings.
Gain practical skills applicable to mechanical design and product development projects.

title: Basic CAD modeling using UG NX, PTC Creo
tagLine: Master the art of CAD modeling
description: This course is designed to introduce participants to the fundamental concepts and techniques of Computer-Aided Design (CAD) using two industry-leading software’s: UG NX and PTC Creo. Through hands-on exercises and practical examples, participants will learn the essential skills required to create 3D models, assemblies, and drawings using both software platforms. By the end of this course, participants will have gained a solid foundation in CAD modeling using UG NX and PTC Creo, enabling them to create and manipulate 3D models efficiently for various engineering applications.
overView: This course introduces students with the user interface of software’s and navigation tools of UG NX and PTC Creo.
Introduce basic sketching techniques for creating 2D profiles.
Educate participants how to create and modify 3D solid models using parametric modeling techniques.
Explore assembly modeling concepts, including component relationships and constraints.
Provide an overview of drawing creation and annotation tools for documenting designs.

title: GD & T ( Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerance )
tagLine: Master the art of Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerance
description: This course provides an in-depth understanding of the principles, concepts, and applications of Geometric Dimensioning and Tolerancing (GD&T). Participants will learn how to create, interpret, and apply GD&T symbols and control frames to engineering drawings, ensuring clear communication of design intent and tolerance requirements.
overView: Understand the fundamental principles and benefits of GD&T.
Interpret engineering drawings containing GD&T symbols and annotations.
Apply GD&T symbols and control frames to specify dimensional and geometric tolerances.
Study the relationship between GD&T, manufacturing processes, and inspection techniques.
Reveal proficiency in using GD&T to communicate design requirements accurately.

faq.question: Introduction to GD&T
answer: Overview of GD&T principles and terminology
Importance of GD&T in engineering design and manufacturing
Historical background and evolution of GD&T standards

faq.question: Basic Dimensioning
answer: Introduction to tolerances and their significance

faq.question: Symbols and Feature Control Frames (FCFs)
answer: Explanation of GD&T symbols: datum, feature control, geometric characteristic symbols
Interpretation of feature control frames (FCFs) on engineering drawings
Representation of tolerances using GD&T symbols

answer: Definition and purpose of datum reference frames (DRFs)
Hierarchical relationship of datums and their impact on part inspection

Practical examples and exercises for form tolerances

answer: Explanation of orientation tolerances: parallelism, perpendicularity, angularity
Proper application of orientation tolerances in engineering drawings

answer: Definition and significance of profile tolerances
Understanding profile of a line (straightness) and profile of a surface (profile)
Practical application and interpretation of profile tolerances

faq.question: Position Tolerances
answer: Explanation of position tolerances: basic dimension, positional tolerance zone, virtual condition
Calculation and interpretation of position tolerances
Case studies illustrating the application of position tolerances

faq.question: Runout and Concentricity Tolerances
answer: Understanding runout tolerances: circular runout, total runout
Interpretation and application of runout tolerances
Introduction to concentricity tolerance and its application

faq.question: Tolerance Stacks and Analysis
answer: Understanding the concept of worst-case and statistical tolerance analysis
Practical techniques for managing tolerance stacks in engineering design

faq.question: GD&T Inspection Methods
answer: Overview of inspection methods for GD&T features
Coordinate measuring machines (CMMs), gauge blocks, optical comparators, etc.
Best practices for GD&T inspection and measurement

faq.question: GD&T in Manufacturing and Quality Control
answer: Integration of GD&T principles into manufacturing processes
Role of GD&T in quality control and assurance
Application of GD&T in ensuring part interchangeability and functionality
